page.addressleaf:
fol.290v
To the right honorable my singular good Lord, the L. Burghley, Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England.
15 Junij
1590
. M
r
Bodeley to my L.
The Ennemies takinge of a fort in
Groninghen
called Eemertell.
15 June 90
page.lettertext:
fol.289r
It may please yo
r
L. to be advertised, that the
Enemie, to divert o
r
forces,
at lie before
Nieu-
meghen
, hath increased his troupes in the territo-
rie of Groeninghen, to
e nomber of 3000 footmen,
and 8 cornet of horse: and hath taken by force
a fort of o
rs
in those quarters called
Eemetil
,
whiche is of some importance. Also sins he is mar-
ched to
e siege of Nieusile, a place adjoining
to
e former. They are situated bothe between
Groeninghen towne, and Rousant
and
by
Groenin-
ghen diepe, but are not sett downe in common mappes.
The
States of Frise
are muche dismaied by this
losse, not only in respect of
e fort, but of their
daunger otherwise, not having in their Province, to
make resistance, above 2000 footmen, and no horse
at all. For whiche cause they have instantly
required some succo
r
from hens, especially of
horse, w
ch
is nowe in consultation. It is fully
resolved, that when
e fort before Nieumeghen
is finished, whiche we hope will be done w
t
in
these 10 daies
Count Maurice
w
t
all his forces,
shall drawe towardes
Zutphen
and
Deventer
,
w
ch
we are many waies almost assured may
be taken by force, and then after shall assist
Count William
in his enterprise on Groeninghen
at w
ch
time, and not before, we shall see what
may be done w
t
her
Ma
ties
letters, which are
yet in my custody.
And thus I take my humble
leave. From
e
Hage
. Junij 15 1590.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden
Tho. Bodley
